title-group.article-title: Clinical Applications of Noninvasive Electrical Stimulation
title-group.subtitle: Problems and Potential

contrib-group.aff: 1UCL Institute of Neurology, Queen Square, London, UK

author-notes.corresp: John C. Rothwell, UCL Institute of Neurology, Queen Square, London, UK Email: j.rothwell@ucl.ac.uk

abstract.p: Both transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) and repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) can produce lasting aftereffects on cortical function that are thought to be due to the initial stages of synaptic potentiation/depression. They can also interact with processes of normal learning, to increase or decrease the rate of learning and retention. These features have spurred a number of investigators to test whether there is any clinical therapeutic potential for the methods to improve recovery of function after damage to the brain by injury or disease. The only condition where there is sufficient evidence is in certain forms of depression where excitatory rTMS is a recommended treatment protocol; there is insufficient evidence for any other condition. The problem facing investigators is the variety of possible paradigms that can be applied. Particularly for tDCS, only a small range of possible parameters has been tested, even in healthy volunteers; in addition, it is unclear whether stimulation should be applied at the same time as a behavioral therapy or whether stimulation should be applied at rest. Present trials give some evidence that can be used to address these questions, but until they are answered more securely it will be difficult to reach a consensus about “standard” protocols that can then be tested widely in multicenter trials.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Brain stimulation as a disease-modifying treatment began with the introduction of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) in 1938 1 ; indeed, ECT is still acknowledged to be a highly effective treatment for refractory depression, particularly if side effects are reduced by careful selection of stimulation parameters. 2 Following this, brain stimulation slowly began to be applied for a variety of other conditions from the early 1950s to the 1980s,3–5 and since the development of fully implantable stimulators in the 1990s, their use in a wide range of different movement and psychiatric disorders has become commonplace. Deep brain stimulation (DBS) of the thalamus, subthalamus, or internal pallidum is a recognized treatment in many parts of the world for tremor, late stage Parkinson disease, and dystonia, while other potential areas of brain are currently under investigation for a range of conditions from pain to depression. Implanted cortical stimulators have also proved to be successful for treatment of chronic pain in a proportion of patients 6 and have also been used in some centers for the treatment of Parkinson disease, 7 although the effects are variable and less reliable compared with DBS.

The development of noninvasive methods of brain stimulation naturally led to the question of whether similar success could be achieved without the need for invasive surgery on the brain. The therapeutic potential of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) began to be explored very soon after the introduction of machines that were capable of repetitive stimulation. Initial efforts concentrated on medication refractory depression, mostly with high-frequency stimulation of the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. Since then there have been more than 140 studies involving more than 1000 patients. 8 Recently, the Food and Drug Administration approved an rTMS protocol as a treatment for medication-resistant depression, indicating that one form of non-invasive brain stimulation has therapeutic clinical potential. Applications to a range of other conditions ranging from stroke to tinnitus are less advanced and only available as part of clinical trials.

Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) in its present form 9 is a relative newcomer to non-invasive therapy trials. However, there are a number of reports from the 1880 s onward regarding its use as a treatment for a number of psychiatric conditions. 10 The best documented are a series of trials in the 1960s for the treatment of depression and schizophrenia. 11,12 In these cases, the authors used stimulation at 0.25 mA for 8 hours daily over 8 weeks with the anode over the orbit and the cathode on the leg. Some degree of success was reported, although later authors 10 and a clinical trial 13 argued that in fact the effects were no greater than placebo. After that time, the advent of new pharmacological agents soon became the favored form of treatment. The recent resurgence of interest in tDCS has provided further insights into the mechanism of action of tDCS and this has led to a steady increase in the number of new therapeutic trials.

sec.title: Therapeutic tDCS
sec.p: Compared with the much larger literature on therapeutic applications of rTMS, there are still relatively few clinical trials using tDCS. Nevertheless, interest is growing steadily, often spurred by practical considerations of relative costs and convenience of application. 14 The majority of trials so far have been to improve movement or speech after stroke, but many other conditions have been tested including depression, schizophrenia, tinnitus, pain, and Parkinson disease. As often in the early stages of a new method, almost all the results show some positive improvement in symptoms, but trial numbers are small and conclusions preliminary. Therefore, it is too early to comment on the potential for tDCS as a clinical therapy. Instead, this paper will ask whether any questions remain about trial designs that might be worth addressing in future studies.

The majority of clinical trials using tDCS have been conducted since 2004 and have had very similar designs: single-session trials test whether a single application (usually up to 30-minute stimulation at 2 mA) of tDCS has immediate effects on a clinical symptom; multiple session trials usually apply tDCS daily (again, usually up to 30 minutes at 2 mA) every weekday for 1 or more weeks. In most cases, anodal stimulation has been applied to increase the excitability of a target region, with the cathode being located elsewhere on the scalp (usually over the contralateral orbit). Finally, in many cases, tDCS is given while patients perform a clinically relevant training task, such as word naming during treatments for aphasia, with the rationale that polarization will enhance the effect of the training protocol. Thus, out of a potentially vast number of possible ways to apply tDCS, only a small range of parameters has been applied. Why is therapeutic tDCS performed in the way it currently is?

sec.title: Intensity of Stimulation
sec.p: The intensity of stimulation should, strictly speaking, be expressed as the current density at the surface of the brain and will therefore depend on the area of the electrode as well as the current intensity and characteristics of the scalp. Modeling studies of the distribution of current in the brain suggest that the latter may be quite different between individuals, particularly in patients with brain lesions that alter the conductivity of the tissue being stimulated. However, most experimental studies so far have avoided dealing with these factors, even in studies in healthy participants (but see Datta et al15 for example).

Although it is easier to control electrode size and stimulus intensity than scalp/brain conductivity, most authors use only a limited range of either parameter. Most reports use electrodes with an area of 25 to 35 cm2 and apply an intensity of 2 mA, giving a mean scalp current density of 0.057 to 0.08 mA/cm2. There have been no detailed studies in clinical populations and very few in healthy volunteers that compare the effectiveness of different electrode sizes and stimulus intensities. One reason for this is that in many cases, the target site for stimulation is large and there is no evidence to expect a greater effect from more focal stimulation so that large electrodes are used by default. Nevertheless, tDCS can be applied in more focal ways if necessary. Nitsche and colleagues 16 compared stimulation with electrodes of 35 versus 3.5 cm2 and found that for a given mean current density at the scalp, the small electrodes had a significantly more focal effect on motor cortex excitability than the large electrode. One proof-of-concept study in healthy volunteers has shown that 20 minutes of “high-definition” tDCS of motor cortex using 1 small anode over the hand area surrounded by 4 small cathodes is tolerated and can reduce perception of pain in the hand. 17 Nevertheless, it was accompanied by significant discomfort on the scalp at the site of stimulation, particularly at the onset of tDCS. Increased spatial resolution might be useful in cases where imaging evidence of areas activated after focal damage suggests that quite focal areas may be better targets at least in some conditions. 18

There are surprisingly few investigations of the effect of stimulus intensity. The initial article from Nitsche and Paulus 9 suggested that the minimal intensity for effects on motor cortical excitability is around 0.5 mA (35 cm2 electrode). Most of the early investigations continued to use 1 mA until Iyer and colleagues 19 used 2 mA during experiments on the effect of frontal lobe stimulation on verbal fluency. They found that 1 mA had no effect, whereas 2 mA increased fluency. However, there was no direct comparison between the effects so that the superiority of 2 mA was not proven (and was not part of the experimental design). A second study on working memory in patients with Parkinson disease also found that 2 mA stimulation over left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex improved memory performance but 1 mA did not. 20 However, there was no significant difference between the intensities. Despite this, most recent tDCS studies now use a 2-mA current. Higher intensities than this are possible but cause scalp irritation and cannot be used for standard tDCS protocols in patients.

sec.title: Stimulus Duration and Frequency of Application
sec.p:
When tDCS was initially used in clinical trials, the main question was how to prolong the after-effect of stimulation. It was assumed that the best behavioral effect would occur after protocols that had the longest after-effects. Most studies suggest that longer periods of continuous tDCS lead to longer lasting after-effects on cortical excitability. 21,22 Duration is only limited by published safety guidelines, which are not very explicit. 19
,23,24 In rats, repeated surface anodal polarization over the dura (approximately 0.4 mA/ cm2 for 30 minutes) can cause abnormal Ca2+ accumulation in cortex, thalamus, and hippocampus, 25 but studies in rats with scalp electrodes suggest safety limits for a single application as much as 100 times higher. 26 In order to avoid very long periods of polarization, after-effects can sometimes be prolonged by applying 2 sessions of tDCS in which the second is given during the after-effects of the first, 27 although in some instances, a homeostatic effect can occur in which the effect of the second application produces the opposite effect to that of the first. 28

However, the duration of the after-effect may not be the most important parameter for achieving optimal clinical effects. If tDCS works by increasing the effectiveness of a training protocol that is executed at the same time as tDCS is applied, then the important effect may be that from training rather than from tDCS (see below).

Linked to the question of duration of each session is the question of how frequently to repeat each session. In terms of the influence on after-effects, in motor cortex these are increased more after daily tDCS than after once every 2 days 29 and in stroke patients, there is greater performance improvement in the Jebsen Taylor test after 5 daily sessions of tDCS compared with a single session.30 In contrast, there was no cumulative effect of 4 weekly sessions of tDCS over and above the effect of a single session given alone, again suggesting that daily application of tDCS is clinically superior to less frequent applications.

sec.title: Stimulus Application During Behavioral Therapy or at Rest?
sec.p:
A number of studies in healthy volunteers has shown that concurrent application of tDCS can improve learning in a variety of motor 31 –33 and cognitive 34
–37 tasks. Thus, many clinical studies make use of this to improve the response of patients to currently accepted behavioral therapies. For example, patients with aphasia may perform picture-naming tasks while being given tDCS 38,39 or arm movements after stroke may be treated with combined tDCS and occupational therapy. 40 The rationale for this approach is that tDCS alone is a nonspecific stimulus and cannot target the particular populations of neurons that might need to strengthen connections in order to improve a behavioral function. This can only be done with training. In effect, training is used to target the effects of tDCS on to appropriate neural circuits to produce behavioral consequences.

It is important to note that when tDCS is used in combination with behavioral therapies, the long-term effects are due to task-dependent learning and hence are not necessarily linked to the duration of any after-effects of tDCS when it is given alone. Paradoxically, this means that although the initial observations that tDCS could have lasting after-effects were important arguments used to justify potential therapeutic applications, it may turn out to be that this is not relevant at all. It may be that the most important effects of tDCS occur online, during the time tDCS interacts with behavioral training. This is not to say that there are no offline effects in such circumstances: experiments on motor learning over several days in healthy individuals have suggested that the majority of the effect of concurrent tDCS is on the consolidation of learning between days rather than on the amount of learning on each day. 32 However, these changes are thought to be a consequence of activity that occurs during training, in the presence of tDCS, rather than an after-effect of tDCS itself.

There are a number of conditions in which tDCS has been applied when patients were at rest and not performing any task such as depression 41 (but see Palm et al 42 for a negative result), tinnitus,43–45 epilepsy, 46,47 pain, 48 Parkinson's disease, 49 migraine, 50 autism, 51 and cravings. 52,53 As noted above, there are too few studies to comment on the possible usefulness of the approaches, but so far, it is not obvious that the results are any better or worse than those in conditions where tDCS has been applied at the same time as a behavioral therapy. Unfortunately, there are no direct comparison trials available. Nevertheless, it is interesting to note that previous work in healthy volunteers had suggested that there might be an important difference in the effect of applying tDCS at the same time as a training protocol compared with before training. Anodal tDCS to motor cortex during implicit learning of a serial reaction time–task improved performance 31 but had no effect when applied before the task 54 ; similarly, after-effects of tDCS on corticospinal excitability are reduced or abolished if tDCS is applied during muscle contraction as compared to rest. 55 The first of these results implies that if function improves because tDCS increases the effectiveness of a training protocol, then it should be applied during practice of that protocol. The second result implies that if function improves because of the after-effects of tDCS, then tDCS should be applied at rest rather than during action. It is even conceivable that different conditions will respond to each approach.

sec.title: Site and Polarity of Stimulation
sec.p:
In the majority of studies, anodal stimulation has been applied over the area of interest in an attempt to increase its function. Some stroke studies have also employed the model of interhemispheric mutual inhibition in which the stroke side is doubly disabled by the focal damage on the stroke side as well as by an increase in inhibition from the non-stroke side. In this case, authors have used inhibitory tDCS over the non-stroke hemisphere to improve function. 39
,56,57 Indeed, several groups have experimented with bifocal stimulation in which the anode is placed on the stroke hemisphere and the cathode on the non-stroke hemisphere. 58,59

However, the application of tDCS in stroke is complex. As several authors have pointed out, the contribution of the non-affected hemisphere to recovery depends not only on the size and location of the lesion 18 but also on the function being assessed. For example, recovery from dysphagia seems to involve increased reliance on connections from the non-stroke hemisphere, 60 and recovery of proximal arm function may follow similar rules in some patients. 61 An additional complexity is time after the stroke: imaging studies suggest that areas contributing to recovered function may change over time, perhaps initially involving the non-stroke hemisphere but later only the stroke hemisphere.

Most clinical studies so far have stimulated with both anode and cathode attached to the scalp. There is some evidence that a non-cephalic electrode can increase the effectiveness of therapeutic stimulation, 62 but more studies are needed to confirm this. Experiments in healthy controls show that extracephalic reference locations may result in less effective stimulation and require higher intensities to achieve the same result. 63 Finally, the relative locations of the electrodes affect the way current spreads in the brain between them. This is likely to dictate which populations of neurons are affected by the DC polarization. However, little is known about the practical consequences of this for therapy.

sec.title: Therapeutic tDCS: Parameters
sec.p: The conclusion from the brief survey above is that, given the available evidence, the usual parameters used for tDCS in clinical trials are near optimal. The problem is that the available evidence is minimal and often limited to response of the healthy brain. The question is what are the important parameters that we can change and which may make a real difference to treatment response? Certain parameters can vary only over a limited range and therefore may not be as important to study. For example, stimulus intensity cannot be much higher than 2 mA since higher currents cause skin irritation very easily; similarly, electrodes cannot be a great deal smaller than those currently in use for similar reasons related to edge effects. Duration of stimulation is also relatively limited if currents of 1 to 2 mA are used, since applications lasting longer than 30 minutes are more likely to cause skin irritation. Lower intensities could, however, be applied for much longer periods. Electrode location is infinitely variable, but in practice the question boils down to; (a) whether the distribution of the electric field in the brain between the electrodes has an important influence on clinical effects and (b) whether an extracephalic electrode is necessary in order to limit local stimulation to 1 scalp site rather than 2.

Perhaps the most important practical question relates to mechanism: should tDCS be applied during a task in order to enhance the natural processes of motor learning or should it be applied to patients at rest because its therapeutic effect relies on after-effects on cortical excitability? We do not know the answer to this, but as pointed out above, if tDCS works by enhancing motor learning then the duration of after-effects may be unimportant. In fact, after-effects from tDCS could even interfere with the natural after-effects of learning itself.

sec.title: The Future of tDCS Therapy
sec.p: tDCS clinical therapy is in its infancy. The development of other forms of stimulation such as random noise or alternating current stimulation 64 increases the number of possible interventions enormously. However, the results so far are encouraging and deserve further work. It is worth learning from the experience of therapeutic rTMS that the pathway to an acceptable application with a clinically relevant effect on patients is difficult and requires very large-scale trials.
